Situation2: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Story: My phone buzzed twice in quick succession. The first message was from Mom, asking if I’d eaten dinner yet and reminding me to send her a photo of my meal, as I always do. The second was from Maya, my best friend, who wrote, “Ugh, today was endless. Can I vent?” I stared at the screen, feeling the familiar tug-of-war inside me. Mom expected me to reply right away, to keep up our daily ritual of sharing every little detail, and I knew she’d worry if I didn’t. But Maya’s message was urgent in a different way—she needed me to listen, to be present and supportive, not distracted or half-hearted. I could already imagine her disappointment if I took too long to answer or seemed distant. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, my heart pounding as I tried to figure out how to be the attentive daughter my parents counted on and the caring friend Maya needed, all at the same time.
